question.title: Maximum length sub-array having absolute difference of adjacent elements either 0 or 1.
question.content:
Given an array ‘A’ of ‘N’ integers, you need to find the maximum length of the sub-array such that the absolute difference between the adjacent elements of the sub-array should be either 0 or 1.

A sub-array is a contiguous section of original elements of the array.

For Example

Let us say  A = [2,4,6,7,6,9], then adjacent elements of sub array [6,7,6] have absolute difference of either 0 or 1 and this is the maximum length sub-array. So the required answer will be 3.

Input Format

The first line contains a single integer ‘T’ denoting the number of test cases.

The first line of each test contains an integer ‘N’ - number of elements in the array.

The second line of each test case contains ‘N’ space-separated integers that make up ‘A’.

Output Format

For each test case, print a single line containing a single integer denoting the maximum length of sub-array having an absolute difference of adjacent elements either 0 or 1.

The output of each test case will be printed in a separate line.

Note:

You do not need to print anything, it has already been taken care of. Just implement the given function.

Constraints

1 <= T <= 50
1 <=N <= 10 ^ 4
-10 ^ 8 <= A[ i ] <=10 ^ 8

Where ‘T’ is the number of test cases, ‘N’ is the number of elements in the array, A[i] is an array element at index ‘i’.

Time limit: 1 sec.

Sample Input 1

2
4
5 7 5 9
5
6 -1 0 1 2

Sample Output 1

1
4

Explanation of Sample Input 1

Test Case 1: We have A = [5, 7, 5, 9]. 
As we can clearly see that no two adjacent elements have an absolute difference of either 0 or 1. So the only sub-array can be any single element of the array. So the answer will be ‘1’.

Test Case 2: The given array is [6, -1, 0, 1, 2].
Sub-array [-1, 0, 1, 2] is the longest sub-array with absolute difference of elements  0 or 1.

Sample Input 2

2
3
9 10 11
6
-2 3 -8 0 4 5

Sample Output 2

3
2

rephrased.body: Given an array of integers, determine the maximum length of a contiguous subarray where the absolute difference between any two adjacent elements is either 0 or 1.

testcases.explanation: No two adjacent elements have an absolute difference of either 0 or 1. Therefore, the longest subarray consists of a single element.
The subarray [-1, 0, 1, 2] is the longest subarray where the absolute difference between adjacent elements is either 0 or 1. Its length is 4.
The subarray [9, 10, 11] is the longest subarray where the absolute difference between adjacent elements is either 0 or 1. Its length is 3.
The subarray [4, 5] is the longest subarray where the absolute difference between adjacent elements is either 0 or 1. Its length is 2.
The entire array [1,2,3,4,5] satisfies the condition since the absolute difference between adjacent elements is always 1.
The entire array [1, 1, 1, 1, 1] satisfies the condition since the absolute difference between adjacent elements is always 0.
The entire array [0, 1, 0, 1, 0, 1] satisfies the condition since the absolute difference between adjacent elements is always 1.
